subject: Re: [junit] Testing philosophy question
msgSnippet: ... I suppose NUnit reports assertion count? JUnit does not. ... Don t worry. I m not going there. I ve been there enough. :) -- J. B. Rainsberger, Diaspar
messageBody:
Ron Jeffries wrote:

> On Thursday, November 20, 2003, at 2:07:13 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> >> Some people would put each assertion into a separate test method.
> >> This is a quasi-religious issue for some.
>
> > For others, it is simply a way to count the number of tests accurately.
>
> As opposed to counting the asserts? Don't they count themselves already? Or
> do you mean the number of test cases? Which, since it equals the number of
> asserts, why do we care?

I suppose NUnit reports assertion count? JUnit does not.

> It's a puzzlement to me. Let's not go there. I apologize.

Don't worry. I'm not going there. I've been there enough. :)
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
